body:
I have problem with MySQL query. These are my tables:
FactAccess:
    IdUser, IdDate, IdTime, IdReferer, IdRequest(int), accessSize, status 
DimRequest: 
    IdRequest (int), requestLine (text), requestMethod (varchar), requestProtocol(varchar)
LogTable: 
    IdUser, accessdate, accesstime, refererName, requestLine(text), requestMethod(varchar), requestProtocol(varchar), accessSize, status

I want to update 6 million rows data of IdRequest from LogTable into FactAccess table. (both tables already have 6 million rows). But, as you can see, FactTable only has IdRequest while the fields from LogTable are requestLine, requestMethod, and requestProtocol, which makes me have to check the requestId to DimRequest table.
Here's my query:
UPDATE FactAccess inner JOIN 
    (SELECT 
          dr.idRequest as idReq, log.idUser as userid, log.accessdate as idDate, log.time as idTime, log.size as accessSize
     FROM 
          DimRequest dr INNER JOIN LogTable log 
     ON 
          dr.requestURL = log.requestLine AND dr.requestMethod = log.request<ethod AND dr.requestProtokol = log.requestProtokol
     ) table2 
ON 
     FactTable.idUser = table2.userid 
     AND 
     FactTable.idDate = table2.idDate 
     AND 
     FactTable.idTime = table2.idTime 
     AND 
     FactTable.accessSize = table2.accessSize
SET 
     FactTable.idRequest = table2.idReq;


that query works well, but it already takes more than 1 hour to finish update 600.000 rows data. Can anyone help me how to optimize that query? Thanks!
sorry for my bad english
title: MySQL update big data takes too much times

body:
In Graphlab, 
I am working with small set of fitness data, to use recommender functions that could provide recommendations. The dataset has userid's column but not item id's, instead different items arranged in columns and their respective ratings in rows corresponding to each userid. In order to use any graphlab recommender method, I need to have userid's and item id's. Here is what I did:
`v = graphlab.SFrame.read_csv('Data.csv')
userId = v["user_id"]
itemId = v["x","y","z","x1","y1","z1"] //x,y,z,x1,y1,z1 are activities that are actually the columns in Data and contains corresponding ratings given by user
sf= graphlab.SFrame({'UserId':userId,'ItemId':itemId})
print sf.head(5)`
Basically, i extracted the user_id col from Data and tried making a column for ItemId using the x,y,z,etc columns extracted from the same data in order to make another sframe with just these 2 columns. This code results in a tabular format sframe with 2 column as expected, but not arranged in the same order I pass arguments in SFrame. So, the output gives ItemId as the first column and then  UserId. Even though I tried to change the order of passing these 2 in sframe, it still gives the same output. Does anyone know the reason why ? 
This is creating a problem further when using any recommender method as it gives the error: Column name user_id does not exist.

In Graphlab, 
I am working with small set of fitness data, to use recommender functions that could provide recommendations. The dataset has userid's column but not item id's, instead different items arranged in columns and their respective ratings in rows corresponding to each userid. In order to use any graphlab recommender method, I need to have userid's and item id's. Here is what I did:
`v = graphlab.SFrame.read_csv('Data.csv')
userId = v["user_id"]
itemId = v["x","y","z","x1","y1","z1"] //x,y,z,x1,y1,z1 are activities that are actually the columns in Data and contains corresponding ratings given by user
sf= graphlab.SFrame({'UserId':userId,'ItemId':itemId})
print sf.head(5)`
Basically, i extracted the user_id col from Data and tried making a column for ItemId using the x,y,z,etc columns extracted from the same data in order to make another sframe with just these 2 columns. This code results in a tabular format sframe with 2 column as expected, but not arranged in the same order I pass arguments in SFrame. So, the output gives ItemId as the first column and then  UserId. Even though I tried to change the order of passing these 2 in sframe, it still gives the same output. Does anyone know the reason why ?

body:
I have problem with MySQL query. These are my tables:
FactAccess:
    IdUser, IdDate, IdTime, IdReferer, IdRequest(int), accessSize, status 
DimRequest: 
    IdRequest (int), requestLine (text), requestMethod (varchar), requestProtocol(varchar)
LogTable: 
    IdUser, accessdate, accesstime, refererName, requestLine(text), requestMethod(varchar), requestProtocol(varchar), accessSize, status

I want to update 6 million rows data of IdRequest from LogTable into FactAccess table. (both tables already have 6 million rows). But, as you can see, FactTable only has IdRequest while the fields from LogTable are requestLine, requestMethod, and requestProtocol, which makes me have to check the requestId to DimRequest table.
Here's my query:
UPDATE FactAccess inner JOIN 
    (SELECT 
          dr.idRequest as idReq, log.idUser as userid, log.accessdate as idDate, log.time as idTime, log.size as accessSize
     FROM 
          DimRequest dr INNER JOIN LogTable log 
     ON 
          dr.requestURL = log.requestLine AND dr.requestMethod = log.request<ethod AND dr.requestProtokol = log.requestProtokol
     ) table2 
ON 
     FactTable.idUser = table2.userid 
     AND 
     FactTable.idDate = table2.idDate 
     AND 
     FactTable.idTime = table2.idTime 
     AND 
     FactTable.accessSize = table2.accessSize
SET 
     FactTable.idRequest = table2.idReq;


that query works well, but it already takes more than 1 hour to finish update 600.000 rows data. Can anyone help me how to optimize that query? Thanks!
sorry for my bad english
title: MySQL update big data takes too much times

I want to subclass UIButton and add to it a property isActive, which is a Bool that changes the look of the button (this is not related to the default .enabled property). 
However, I also want to set the button type when initialized. Specifically, I want to initialize it much like it is in UIButton, like:
let button = MyButton(type: .Custom)

However, because the .buttonType is a read-only, I cannot just override it like:
convenience init(type buttonType: UIButtonType) {
    buttonType = buttonType
    self.init()
}

This spits out an error: Cannot assign to value: 'buttonType' is a 'let' constant (I already implemented the required init(coder:)).
So how can I set the .buttonType when initialized?

NOTE: The custom property shall be also used in other functions to change the logic within it, so I picked up a property, instead of defining two functions to change the look.
title: How to override UIButton's init with button type in Swift?

body:
In Graphlab, 
I am working with small set of fitness data, to use recommender functions that could provide recommendations. The dataset has userid's column but not item id's, instead different items arranged in columns and their respective ratings in rows corresponding to each userid. In order to use any graphlab recommender method, I need to have userid's and item id's. Here is what I did:
`v = graphlab.SFrame.read_csv('Data.csv')
userId = v["user_id"]
itemId = v["x","y","z","x1","y1","z1"] //x,y,z,x1,y1,z1 are activities that are actually the columns in Data and contains corresponding ratings given by user
sf= graphlab.SFrame({'UserId':userId,'ItemId':itemId})
print sf.head(5)`
Basically, i extracted the user_id col from Data and tried making a column for ItemId using the x,y,z,etc columns extracted from the same data in order to make another sframe with just these 2 columns. This code results in a tabular format sframe with 2 column as expected, but not arranged in the same order I pass arguments in SFrame. So, the output gives ItemId as the first column and then  UserId. Even though I tried to change the order of passing these 2 in sframe, it still gives the same output. Does anyone know the reason why ? 
This is creating a problem further when using any recommender method as it gives the error: Column name user_id does not exist.
title: Grpahlab SFrames: Error in using SFrames with the dataset

I want to rank an array such as the following:
mat[0] = 300  
mat[1] = 200  
mat[2] = 360  
mat[3] = 230  
mat[4] = 290  

The rank depends on the array above (max number gets rank 1 etc.):
rank[0] = 2  
rank[1] = 5  
rank[2] = 1  
rank[3] = 4  
rank[4] = 3  

How do I rank without moving the array in any kind of sorting algorithm 
or by having different input:
mat[0] = 400 
mat[1] = 100  
mat[2] = 220  
mat[3] = 230  
mat[4] = 50  

the rank would be:
rank[0] = 1  
rank[1] = 4  
rank[2] = 3  
rank[3] = 2  
rank[4] = 5

How would I do this in C?
title: How do I rank an array of numbers in C without moving them from place?

body:
I have problem with MySQL query. These are my tables:
FactAccess:
    IdUser, IdDate, IdTime, IdReferer, IdRequest(int), accessSize, status 
DimRequest: 
    IdRequest (int), requestLine (text), requestMethod (varchar), requestProtocol(varchar)
LogTable: 
    IdUser, accessdate, accesstime, refererName, requestLine(text), requestMethod(varchar), requestProtocol(varchar), accessSize, status

I want to update 6 million rows data of IdRequest from LogTable into FactAccess table. (both tables already have 6 million rows). But, as you can see, FactTable only has IdRequest while the fields from LogTable are requestLine, requestMethod, and requestProtocol, which makes me have to check the requestId to DimRequest table.
Here's my query:
UPDATE FactAccess inner JOIN 
    (SELECT 
          dr.idRequest as idReq, log.idUser as userid, log.accessdate as idDate, log.time as idTime, log.size as accessSize
     FROM 
          DimRequest dr INNER JOIN LogTable log 
     ON 
          dr.requestURL = log.requestLine AND dr.requestMethod = log.request<ethod AND dr.requestProtokol = log.requestProtokol
     ) table2 
ON 
     FactTable.idUser = table2.userid 
     AND 
     FactTable.idDate = table2.idDate 
     AND 
     FactTable.idTime = table2.idTime 
     AND 
     FactTable.accessSize = table2.accessSize
SET 
     FactTable.idRequest = table2.idReq;


that query works well, but it already takes more than 1 hour to finish update 600.000 rows data. Can anyone help me how to optimize that query? Thanks!
sorry for my bad english
title: MySQL update big data takes too much times

<input type="password" name="password" placeholder="Password">

body:
I have problem with MySQL query. These are my tables:
FactAccess:
    IdUser, IdDate, IdTime, IdReferer, IdRequest(int), accessSize, status 
DimRequest: 
    IdRequest (int), requestLine (text), requestMethod (varchar), requestProtocol(varchar)
LogTable: 
    IdUser, accessdate, accesstime, refererName, requestLine(text), requestMethod(varchar), requestProtocol(varchar), accessSize, status

I want to update 6 million rows data of IdRequest from LogTable into FactAccess table. (both tables already have 6 million rows). But, as you can see, FactTable only has IdRequest while the fields from LogTable are requestLine, requestMethod, and requestProtocol, which makes me have to check the requestId to DimRequest table.
Here's my query:
UPDATE FactAccess inner JOIN 
    (SELECT 
          dr.idRequest as idReq, log.idUser as userid, log.accessdate as idDate, log.time as idTime, log.size as accessSize
     FROM 
          DimRequest dr INNER JOIN LogTable log 
     ON 
          dr.requestURL = log.requestLine AND dr.requestMethod = log.request<ethod AND dr.requestProtokol = log.requestProtokol
     ) table2 
ON 
     FactTable.idUser = table2.userid 
     AND 
     FactTable.idDate = table2.idDate 
     AND 
     FactTable.idTime = table2.idTime 
     AND 
     FactTable.accessSize = table2.accessSize
SET 
     FactTable.idRequest = table2.idReq;


that query works well, but it already takes more than 1 hour to finish update 600.000 rows data. Can anyone help me how to optimize that query? Thanks!
sorry for my bad english
title: MySQL update big data takes too much times

In Graphlab, 
I am working with small set of fitness data, to use recommender functions that could provide recommendations. The dataset has userid's column but not item id's, instead different items arranged in columns and their respective ratings in rows corresponding to each userid. In order to use any graphlab recommender method, I need to have userid's and item id's. Here is what I did:
`v = graphlab.SFrame.read_csv('Data.csv')
userId = v["user_id"]
itemId = v["x","y","z","x1","y1","z1"] //x,y,z,x1,y1,z1 are activities that are actually the columns in Data and contains corresponding ratings given by user
sf= graphlab.SFrame({'UserId':userId,'ItemId':itemId})
print sf.head(5)`
Basically, i extracted the user_id col from Data and tried making a column for ItemId using the x,y,z,etc columns extracted from the same data in order to make another sframe with just these 2 columns. This code results in a tabular format sframe with 2 column as expected, but not arranged in the same order I pass arguments in SFrame. So, the output gives ItemId as the first column and then  UserId. Even though I tried to change the order of passing these 2 in sframe, it still gives the same output. body:
I have problem with MySQL query. These are my tables:
FactAccess:
    IdUser, IdDate, IdTime, IdReferer, IdRequest(int), accessSize, status 
DimRequest: 
    IdRequest (int), requestLine (text), requestMethod (varchar), requestProtocol(varchar)
LogTable: 
    IdUser, accessdate, accesstime, refererName, requestLine(text), requestMethod(varchar), requestProtocol(varchar), accessSize, status

I want to update 6 million rows data of IdRequest from LogTable into FactAccess table. (both tables already have 6 million rows). But, as you can see, FactTable only has IdRequest while the fields from LogTable are requestLine, requestMethod, and requestProtocol, which makes me have to check the requestId to DimRequest table.
Here's my query:
UPDATE FactAccess inner JOIN 
    (SELECT 
          dr.idRequest as idReq, log.idUser as userid, log.accessdate as idDate, log.time as idTime, log.size as accessSize
     FROM 
          DimRequest dr INNER JOIN LogTable log 
     ON 
          dr.requestURL = log.requestLine AND dr.requestMethod = log.request<ethod AND dr.requestProtokol = log.requestProtokol
     ) table2 
ON 
     FactTable.idUser = table2.userid 
     AND 
     FactTable.idDate = table2.idDate 
     AND 
     FactTable.idTime = table2.idTime 
     AND 
     FactTable.accessSize = table2.accessSize
SET 
     FactTable.idRequest = table2.idReq;


that query works well, but it already takes more than 1 hour to finish update 600.000 rows data. Can anyone help me how to optimize that query? Thanks!
sorry for my bad english
title: MySQL update big data takes too much times

In Graphlab, 
I am working with small set of fitness data, to use recommender functions that could provide recommendations. The dataset has userid's column but not item id's, instead different items arranged in columns and their respective ratings in rows corresponding to each userid. In order to use any graphlab recommender method, I need to have userid's and item id's. Here is what I did:
`v = graphlab.SFrame.read_csv('Data.csv')
userId = v["user_id"]
itemId = v["x","y","z","x1","y1","z1"] //x,y,z,x1,y1,z1 are activities that are actually the columns in Data and contains corresponding ratings given by user
sf= graphlab.SFrame({'UserId':userId,'ItemId':itemId})
print sf.head(5)`
Basically, i extracted the user_id col from Data and tried making a column for ItemId using the x,y,z,etc columns extracted from the same data in order to make another sframe with just these 2 columns. This code results in a tabular format sframe with 2 column as expected, but not arranged in the same order I pass arguments in SFrame. So, the output gives ItemId as the first column and then  UserId. Even though I tried to change the order of passing these 2 in sframe, it still gives the same output. body:
I have problem with MySQL query. These are my tables:
FactAccess:
    IdUser, IdDate, IdTime, IdReferer, IdRequest(int), accessSize, status 
DimRequest: 
    IdRequest (int), requestLine (text), requestMethod (varchar), requestProtocol(varchar)
LogTable: 
    IdUser, accessdate, accesstime, refererName, requestLine(text), requestMethod(varchar), requestProtocol(varchar), accessSize, status

I want to update 6 million rows data of IdRequest from LogTable into FactAccess table. (both tables already have 6 million rows). But, as you can see, FactTable only has IdRequest while the fields from LogTable are requestLine, requestMethod, and requestProtocol, which makes me have to check the requestId to DimRequest table.
Here's my query:
UPDATE FactAccess inner JOIN 
    (SELECT 
          dr.idRequest as idReq, log.idUser as userid, log.accessdate as idDate, log.time as idTime, log.size as accessSize
     FROM 
          DimRequest dr INNER JOIN LogTable log 
     ON 
          dr.requestURL = log.requestLine AND dr.requestMethod = log.request<ethod AND dr.requestProtokol = log.requestProtokol
     ) table2 
ON 
     FactTable.idUser = table2.userid 
     AND 
     FactTable.idDate = table2.idDate 
     AND 
     FactTable.idTime = table2.idTime 
     AND 
     FactTable.accessSize = table2.accessSize
SET 
     FactTable.idRequest = table2.idReq;


that query works well, but it already takes more than 1 hour to finish update 600.000 rows data. Can anyone help me how to optimize that query? Thanks!
sorry for my bad english
title: MySQL update big data takes too much times

body:
I have problem with MySQL query. These are my tables:
FactAccess:
    IdUser, IdDate, IdTime, IdReferer, IdRequest(int), accessSize, status 
DimRequest: 
    IdRequest (int), requestLine (text), requestMethod (varchar), requestProtocol(varchar)
LogTable: 
    IdUser, accessdate, accesstime, refererName, requestLine(text), requestMethod(varchar), requestProtocol(varchar), accessSize, status

I want to update 6 million rows data of IdRequest from LogTable into FactAccess table. (both tables already have 6 million rows). But, as you can see, FactTable only has IdRequest while the fields from LogTable are requestLine, requestMethod, and requestProtocol, which makes me have to check the requestId to DimRequest table.
Here's my query:
UPDATE FactAccess inner JOIN 
    (SELECT 
          dr.idRequest as idReq, log.idUser as userid, log.accessdate as idDate, log.time as idTime, log.size as accessSize
     FROM 
          DimRequest dr INNER JOIN LogTable log 
     ON 
          dr.requestURL = log.requestLine AND dr.requestMethod = log.request<ethod AND dr.requestProtokol = log.requestProtokol
     ) table2 
ON 
     FactTable.idUser = table2.userid 
     AND 
     FactTable.idDate = table2.idDate 
     AND 
     FactTable.idTime = table2.idTime 
     AND 
     FactTable.accessSize = table2.accessSize
SET 
     FactTable.idRequest = table2.idReq;


that query works well, but it already takes more than 1 hour to finish update 600.000 rows data. Can anyone help me how to optimize that query? Thanks!
sorry for my bad english
title: MySQL update big data takes too much times

A student must complete the basic level before entering

body:
I have problem with MySQL query. These are my tables:
FactAccess:
    IdUser, IdDate, IdTime, IdReferer, IdRequest(int), accessSize, status 
DimRequest: 
    IdRequest (int), requestLine (text), requestMethod (varchar), requestProtocol(varchar)
LogTable: 
    IdUser, accessdate, accesstime, refererName, requestLine(text), requestMethod(varchar), requestProtocol(varchar), accessSize, status

I want to update 6 million rows data of IdRequest from LogTable into FactAccess table. (both tables already have 6 million rows). But, as you can see, FactTable only has IdRequest while the fields from LogTable are requestLine, requestMethod, and requestProtocol, which makes me have to check the requestId to DimRequest table.
Here's my query:
UPDATE FactAccess inner JOIN 
    (SELECT 
          dr.idRequest as idReq, log.idUser as userid, log.accessdate as idDate, log.time as idTime, log.size as accessSize
     FROM 
          DimRequest dr INNER JOIN LogTable log 
     ON 
          dr.requestURL = log.requestLine AND dr.requestMethod = log.request<ethod AND dr.requestProtokol = log.requestProtokol
     ) table2 
ON 
     FactTable.idUser = table2.userid 
     AND 
     FactTable.idDate = table2.idDate 
     AND 
     FactTable.idTime = table2.idTime 
     AND 
     FactTable.accessSize = table2.accessSize
SET 
     FactTable.idRequest = table2.idReq;


that query works well, but it already takes more than 1 hour to finish update 600.000 rows data. Can anyone help me how to optimize that query? Thanks!
sorry for my bad english
title: MySQL update big data takes too much times

In Graphlab,

In order to use any graphlab recommender method, I need to have userid's and item id's. Here is what I did:
`v = graphlab.SFrame.read_csv('Data.csv')
userId = v["user_id"]
itemId = v["x","y","z","x1","y1","z1"] //x,y,z,x1,y1,z1 are activities that are actually the columns in Data and contains corresponding ratings given by user
sf= graphlab.SFrame({'UserId':userId,'ItemId':itemId})
print sf.head(5)`
Basically, i extracted the user_id col from Data and tried making a column for ItemId using the x,y,z,etc columns extracted from the same data in order to make another sframe with just these 2 columns. This code results in a tabular format sframe with 2 column as expected, but not arranged in the same order I pass arguments in SFrame. So, the output gives ItemId as the first column and then  UserId. Even though I tried to change the order of passing these 2 in sframe, it still gives the same output. body:
I have problem with MySQL query. These are my tables:
FactAccess:
    IdUser, IdDate, IdTime, IdReferer, IdRequest(int), accessSize, status 
DimRequest: 
    IdRequest (int), requestLine (text), requestMethod (varchar), requestProtocol(varchar)
LogTable: 
    IdUser, accessdate, accesstime, refererName, requestLine(text), requestMethod(varchar), requestProtocol(varchar), accessSize, status

I want to update 6 million rows data of IdRequest from LogTable into FactAccess table. (both tables already have 6 million rows). But, as you can see, FactTable only has IdRequest while the fields from LogTable are requestLine, requestMethod, and requestProtocol, which makes me have to check the requestId to DimRequest table.
Here's my query:
UPDATE FactAccess inner JOIN 
    (SELECT 
          dr.idRequest as idReq, log.idUser as userid, log.accessdate as idDate, log.time as idTime, log.size as accessSize
     FROM 
          DimRequest dr INNER JOIN LogTable log 
     ON 
          dr.requestURL = log.requestLine AND dr.requestMethod = log.request<ethod AND dr.requestProtokol = log.requestProtokol
     ) table2 
ON 
     FactTable.idUser = table2.userid 
     AND 
     FactTable.idDate = table2.idDate 
     AND 
     FactTable.idTime = table2.idTime 
     AND 
     FactTable.accessSize = table2.accessSize
SET 
     FactTable.idRequest = table2.idReq;


that query works well, but it already takes more than 1 hour to finish update 600.000 rows data. Can anyone help me how to optimize that query? Thanks!
sorry for my bad english
title: MySQL update big data takes too much times

However, I also want to set the button type when initialized. Specifically, I want to initialize it much like it is in UIButton, like:
let button = MyButton(type: .Custom)

However, because the .buttonType is a read-only, I cannot just override it like:
convenience init(type buttonType: UIButtonType) {
    buttonType = buttonType
    self.init()
}

This spits out an error: Cannot assign to value: 'buttonType' is a 'let' constant (I already implemented the required init(coder:)).
So how can I set the .buttonType when initialized?

NOTE: The custom property shall be also used in other functions to change the logic within it, so I picked up a property, instead of defining two functions to change the look.
title: How to override UIButton's init with button type in Swift?

I am working with small set of fitness data, to use recommender functions that could provide recommendations. The dataset has userid's column but not item id's, instead different items arranged in columns and their respective ratings in rows corresponding to each userid. In order to use any graphlab recommender method, I need to have userid's and item id's. Here is what I did:
`v = graphlab.SFrame.read_csv('Data.csv')
userId = v["user_id"]
itemId = v["x","y","z","x1","y1","z1"] //x,y,z,x1,y1,z1 are activities that are actually the columns in Data and contains corresponding ratings given by user
sf= graphlab.SFrame({'UserId':userId,'ItemId':itemId})
print sf.head(5)`
Basically, i extracted the user_id col from Data and tried making a column for ItemId using the x,y,z,etc columns extracted from the same data in order to make another sframe with just these 2 columns. This code results in a tabular format sframe with 2 column as expected, but not arranged in the same order I pass arguments in SFrame. So, the output gives ItemId as the first column and then  UserId. Even though I tried to change the order of passing these 2 in sframe, it still gives the same output. Does anyone know the reason why ? 
This is creating a problem further when using any recommender method as it gives the error: Column name user_id does not exist.

body:
I have problem with MySQL query. These are my tables:
FactAccess:
    IdUser, IdDate, IdTime, IdReferer, IdRequest(int), accessSize, status 
DimRequest: 
    IdRequest (int), requestLine (text), requestMethod (varchar), requestProtocol(varchar)
LogTable: 
    IdUser, accessdate, accesstime, refererName, requestLine(text), requestMethod(varchar), requestProtocol(varchar), accessSize, status

I want to update 6 million rows data of IdRequest from LogTable into FactAccess table. (both tables already have 6 million rows). But, as you can see, FactTable only has IdRequest while the fields from LogTable are requestLine, requestMethod, and requestProtocol, which makes me have to check the requestId to DimRequest table.
Here's my query:
UPDATE FactAccess inner JOIN 
    (SELECT 
          dr.idRequest as idReq, log.idUser as userid, log.accessdate as idDate, log.time as idTime, log.size as accessSize
     FROM 
          DimRequest dr INNER JOIN LogTable log 
     ON 
          dr.requestURL = log.requestLine AND dr.requestMethod = log.request<ethod AND dr.requestProtokol = log.requestProtokol
     ) table2 
ON 
     FactTable.idUser = table2.userid 
     AND 
     FactTable.idDate = table2.idDate 
     AND 
     FactTable.idTime = table2.idTime 
     AND 
     FactTable.accessSize = table2.accessSize
SET 
     FactTable.idRequest = table2.idReq;


that query works well, but it already takes more than 1 hour to finish update 600.000 rows data. Can anyone help me how to optimize that query? Thanks!
sorry for my bad english
title: MySQL update big data takes too much times

    IdUser, IdDate, IdTime, IdReferer, IdRequest(int), accessSize, status 
DimRequest: 
    IdRequest (int), requestLine (text), requestMethod (varchar), requestProtocol(varchar)
LogTable: 
    IdUser, accessdate, accesstime, refererName, requestLine(text), requestMethod(varchar), requestProtocol(varchar), accessSize, status

I want to update 6 million rows data of IdRequest from LogTable into FactAccess table. (both tables already have 6 million rows). But, as you can see, FactTable only has IdRequest while the fields from LogTable are requestLine, requestMethod, and requestProtocol, which makes me have to check the requestId to DimRequest table.
Here's my query:
UPDATE FactAccess inner JOIN 
    (SELECT 
          dr.idRequest as idReq, log.idUser as userid, log.accessdate as idDate, log.time as idTime, log.size as accessSize
     FROM 
          DimRequest dr INNER JOIN LogTable log 
     ON 
          dr.requestURL = log.requestLine AND dr.requestMethod = log.request<ethod AND dr.requestProtokol = log.requestProtokol
     ) table2 
ON 
     FactTable.idUser = table2.userid 
     AND 
     FactTable.idDate = table2.idDate 
     AND 
     FactTable.idTime = table2.idTime 
     AND 
     FactTable.accessSize = table2.accessSize
SET 
     FactTable.idRequest = table2.idReq;


that query works well, but it already takes more than 1 hour to finish update 600.000 rows data. Can anyone help me how to optimize that query? Thanks!
sorry for my bad english
title: MySQL update big data takes too much times

body:
I have problem with MySQL query. These are my tables:
FactAccess:
    IdUser, IdDate, IdTime, IdReferer, IdRequest(int), accessSize, status 
DimRequest: 
    IdRequest (int), requestLine (text), requestMethod (varchar), requestProtocol(varchar)
LogTable: 
    IdUser, accessdate, accesstime, refererName, requestLine(text), requestMethod(varchar), requestProtocol(varchar), accessSize, status

I want to update 6 million rows data of IdRequest from LogTable into FactAccess table. (both tables already have 6 million rows). But, as you can see, FactTable only has IdRequest while the fields from LogTable are requestLine, requestMethod, and requestProtocol, which makes me have to check the requestId to DimRequest table.
Here's my query:
UPDATE FactAccess inner JOIN 
    (SELECT 
          dr.idRequest as idReq, log.idUser as userid, log.accessdate as idDate, log.time as idTime, log.size as accessSize
     FROM 
          DimRequest dr INNER JOIN LogTable log 
     ON 
          dr.requestURL = log.requestLine AND dr.requestMethod = log.request<ethod AND dr.requestProtokol = log.requestProtokol
     ) table2 
ON 
     FactTable.idUser = table2.userid 
     AND 
     FactTable.idDate = table2.idDate 
     AND 
     FactTable.idTime = table2.idTime 
     AND 
     FactTable.accessSize = table2.accessSize
SET 
     FactTable.idRequest = table2.idReq;


that query works well, but it already takes more than 1 hour to finish update 600.000 rows data. Can anyone help me how to optimize that query? Thanks!
sorry for my bad english
title: MySQL update big data takes too much times

body:
I want to subclass UIButton and add to it a property isActive, which is a Bool that changes the look of the button (this is not related to the default .enabled property). 
However, I also want to set the button type when initialized. Specifically, I want to initialize it much like it is in UIButton, like:
let button = MyButton(type: .Custom)

However, because the .buttonType is a read-only, I cannot just override it like:
convenience init(type buttonType: UIButtonType) {
    buttonType = buttonType
    self.init()
}

This spits out an error: Cannot assign to value: 'buttonType' is a 'let' constant (I already implemented the required init(coder:)).
So how can I set the .buttonType when initialized?

NOTE: The custom property shall be also used in other functions to change the logic within it, so I picked up a property, instead of defining two functions to change the look.
title: How to override UIButton's init with button type in Swift?

body:
I have problem with MySQL query. These are my tables:
FactAccess:
    IdUser, IdDate, IdTime, IdReferer, IdRequest(int), accessSize, status 
DimRequest: 
    IdRequest (int), requestLine (text), requestMethod (varchar), requestProtocol(varchar)
LogTable: 
    IdUser, accessdate, accesstime, refererName, requestLine(text), requestMethod(varchar), requestProtocol(varchar), accessSize, status

I want to update 6 million rows data of IdRequest from LogTable into FactAccess table. (both tables already have 6 million rows). But, as you can see, FactTable only has IdRequest while the fields from LogTable are requestLine, requestMethod, and requestProtocol, which makes me have to check the requestId to DimRequest table.
Here's my query:
UPDATE FactAccess inner JOIN 
    (SELECT 
          dr.idRequest as idReq, log.idUser as userid, log.accessdate as idDate, log.time as idTime, log.size as accessSize
     FROM 
          DimRequest dr INNER JOIN LogTable log 
     ON 
          dr.requestURL = log.requestLine AND dr.requestMethod = log.request<ethod AND dr.requestProtokol = log.requestProtokol
     ) table2 
ON 
     FactTable.idUser = table2.userid 
     AND 
     FactTable.idDate = table2.idDate 
     AND 
     FactTable.idTime = table2.idTime 
     AND 
     FactTable.accessSize = table2.accessSize
SET 
     FactTable.idRequest = table2.idReq;


that query works well, but it already takes more than 1 hour to finish update 600.000 rows data. Can anyone help me how to optimize that query? Thanks!
sorry for my bad english
title: MySQL update big data takes too much times

body:
I want to subclass UIButton and add to it a property isActive, which is a Bool that changes the look of the button (this is not related to the default .enabled property). 
However, I also want to set the button type when initialized. Specifically, I want to initialize it much like it is in UIButton, like:
let button = MyButton(type: .Custom)

However, because the .buttonType is a read-only, I cannot just override it like:
convenience init(type buttonType: UIButtonType) {
    buttonType = buttonType
    self.init()
}

This spits out an error: Cannot assign to value: 'buttonType' is a 'let' constant (I already implemented the required init(coder:)).
So how can I set the .buttonType when initialized?

NOTE: The custom property shall be also used in other functions to change the logic within it, so I picked up a property, instead of defining two functions to change the look.
title: How to override UIButton's init with button type in Swift?

In Graphlab, 
I am working with small set of fitness data, to use recommender functions that could provide recommendations. The dataset has userid's column but not item id's, instead different items arranged in columns and their respective ratings in rows corresponding to each userid. In order to use any graphlab recommender method, I need to have userid's and item id's. Here is what I did:
`v = graphlab.SFrame.read_csv('Data.csv')
userId = v["user_id"]
itemId = v["x","y","z","x1","y1","z1"] //x,y,z,x1,y1,z1 are activities that are actually the columns in Data and contains corresponding ratings given by user
sf= graphlab.SFrame({'UserId':userId,'ItemId':itemId})
print sf.head(5)`
Basically, i extracted the user_id col from Data and tried making a column for ItemId using the x,y,z,etc columns extracted from the same data in order to make another sframe with just these 2 columns. This code results in a tabular format sframe with 2 column as expected, but not arranged in the same order I pass arguments in SFrame. So, the output gives ItemId as the first column and then  UserId. Even though I tried to change the order of passing these 2 in sframe, it still gives the same output. Does anyone know the reason why ? 
This is creating a problem further when using any recommender method as it gives the error: Column name user_id does not exist.

body:
I have problem with MySQL query. These are my tables:
FactAccess:
    IdUser, IdDate, IdTime, IdReferer, IdRequest(int), accessSize, status 
DimRequest: 
    IdRequest (int), requestLine (text), requestMethod (varchar), requestProtocol(varchar)
LogTable: 
    IdUser, accessdate, accesstime, refererName, requestLine(text), requestMethod(varchar), requestProtocol(varchar), accessSize, status

I want to update 6 million rows data of IdRequest from LogTable into FactAccess table. (both tables already have 6 million rows). But, as you can see, FactTable only has IdRequest while the fields from LogTable are requestLine, requestMethod, and requestProtocol, which makes me have to check the requestId to DimRequest table.
Here's my query:
UPDATE FactAccess inner JOIN 
    (SELECT 
          dr.idRequest as idReq, log.idUser as userid, log.accessdate as idDate, log.time as idTime, log.size as accessSize
     FROM 
          DimRequest dr INNER JOIN LogTable log 
     ON 
          dr.requestURL = log.requestLine AND dr.requestMethod = log.request<ethod AND dr.requestProtokol = log.requestProtokol
     ) table2 
ON 
     FactTable.idUser = table2.userid 
     AND 
     FactTable.idDate = table2.idDate 
     AND 
     FactTable.idTime = table2.idTime 
     AND 
     FactTable.accessSize = table2.accessSize
SET 
     FactTable.idRequest = table2.idReq;


that query works well, but it already takes more than 1 hour to finish update 600.000 rows data. Can anyone help me how to optimize that query? Thanks!
sorry for my bad english
title: MySQL update big data takes too much times

body:
I have problem with MySQL query. These are my tables:
FactAccess:
    IdUser, IdDate, IdTime, IdReferer, IdRequest(int), accessSize, status 
DimRequest: 
    IdRequest (int), requestLine (text), requestMethod (varchar), requestProtocol(varchar)
LogTable: 
    IdUser, accessdate, accesstime, refererName, requestLine(text), requestMethod(varchar), requestProtocol(varchar), accessSize, status

I want to update 6 million rows data of IdRequest from LogTable into FactAccess table. (both tables already have 6 million rows). But, as you can see, FactTable only has IdRequest while the fields from LogTable are requestLine, requestMethod, and requestProtocol, which makes me have to check the requestId to DimRequest table.
Here's my query:
UPDATE FactAccess inner JOIN 
    (SELECT 
          dr.idRequest as idReq, log.idUser as userid, log.accessdate as idDate, log.time as idTime, log.size as accessSize
     FROM 
          DimRequest dr INNER JOIN LogTable log 
     ON 
          dr.requestURL = log.requestLine AND dr.requestMethod = log.request<ethod AND dr.requestProtokol = log.requestProtokol
     ) table2 
ON 
     FactTable.idUser = table2.userid 
     AND 
     FactTable.idDate = table2.idDate 
     AND 
     FactTable.idTime = table2.idTime 
     AND 
     FactTable.accessSize = table2.accessSize
SET 
     FactTable.idRequest = table2.idReq;


that query works well, but it already takes more than 1 hour to finish update 600.000 rows data. Can anyone help me how to optimize that query? Thanks!
sorry for my bad english
title: MySQL update big data takes too much times

In order to use any graphlab recommender method, I need to have userid's and item id's. Here is what I did:
`v = graphlab.SFrame.read_csv('Data.csv')
userId = v["user_id"]
itemId = v["x","y","z","x1","y1","z1"] //x,y,z,x1,y1,z1 are activities that are actually the columns in Data and contains corresponding ratings given by user
sf= graphlab.SFrame({'UserId':userId,'ItemId':itemId})
print sf.head(5)`

itemId = v["x","y","z","x1","y1","z1"] //x,y,z,x1,y1,z1 are activities that are actually the columns in Data and contains corresponding ratings given by user

body:
I have problem with MySQL query. These are my tables:
FactAccess:
    IdUser, IdDate, IdTime, IdReferer, IdRequest(int), accessSize, status 
DimRequest: 
    IdRequest (int), requestLine (text), requestMethod (varchar), requestProtocol(varchar)
LogTable: 
    IdUser, accessdate, accesstime, refererName, requestLine(text), requestMethod(varchar), requestProtocol(varchar), accessSize, status

I want to update 6 million rows data of IdRequest from LogTable into FactAccess table. (both tables already have 6 million rows). But, as you can see, FactTable only has IdRequest while the fields from LogTable are requestLine, requestMethod, and requestProtocol, which makes me have to check the requestId to DimRequest table.
Here's my query:
UPDATE FactAccess inner JOIN 
    (SELECT 
          dr.idRequest as idReq, log.idUser as userid, log.accessdate as idDate, log.time as idTime, log.size as accessSize
     FROM 
          DimRequest dr INNER JOIN LogTable log 
     ON 
          dr.requestURL = log.requestLine AND dr.requestMethod = log.request<ethod AND dr.requestProtokol = log.requestProtokol
     ) table2 
ON 
     FactTable.idUser = table2.userid 
     AND 
     FactTable.idDate = table2.idDate 
     AND 
     FactTable.idTime = table2.idTime 
     AND 
     FactTable.accessSize = table2.accessSize
SET 
     FactTable.idRequest = table2.idReq;


that query works well, but it already takes more than 1 hour to finish update 600.000 rows data. Can anyone help me how to optimize that query? Thanks!
sorry for my bad english
title: MySQL update big data takes too much times

body:
Have a problem to add legend to different smooth in ggplot.
    library(splines)
    library(ggplot2)
    temp <- data.frame(x = rnorm(200, 20, 15), y = rnorm(200, 30, 8))

    ggplot(data = temp, aes(x, y)) + geom_point() + 
      geom_smooth(method = 'lm', formula = y ~ bs(x, df=5, intercept = T), col='blue') + 
      geom_smooth(method = 'lm', formula = y ~ ns(x, df=2, intercept = T), col='red')

I have two splines: red and blue. How I can add a legend for them?
title: How to add legend to geom_smooth in ggplot in R

I have implemented tablix inside tablix concept. I done this with the help of following link.
I have one table A, that is holding other two tables B & C respectively. I have grouped these two tables with the help of Dept_Nbr from first table A. 

What I want is:
I want to give page break in between two tables. For example, I have Dept_Nbr as 529 and 530. In one page, the two tables will show the records for 529 and in the other page the two tables will show the records for 530. 
Now I want to show all these records in four pages. first table is in one page and second table is in other page for 529th Dept_nbr and vice versa for 530.
How to give Page break inside grouping.
What I tried is:

I gave Page Break on Group Properties, Hence Page is breaking in between two groups. But I want a page break inside a group itself.
Also I checked the check box on tablix properties i.e.., Add Page Break Before and Add Page Break After. But nothing gives the output as it is already in grouping.
